projectDesc.p: "About the prostitute who complained about the barber’s evil deed" is published by The Global Medieval Sourcebook (GMS), a free, open access, and open source compendium of medieval texts in their original languages and in English translation. GMS comprises computer-readable transcriptions or editions alongside new translations of texts dating from the ninth to the sixteenth century and originating in Europe, North Africa, the Middle East, and Asia. The GMS platform includes critical introductions as well as sources for further reading.

editorialDecl.p: Transcriptions and translations are encoded in XML conforming to TEI (P5) guidelines. The original-language text is contained within <lem> tags and translations within <rdg> tags.

interpretation.p: Texts are translated into modern American English with maximum fidelity to the original text, except where it would impair comprehension or good style. Archaisms are preserved where they do not conflict with the aesthetic of the original text. Scribal errors and creative translation choices are marked and discussed in the critical notes.

app.lem: Magistratus est Florentiae, quem Officiales honestatis vocant:
app.rdg: In Florence there is a magistracy called the Office of Respectability,

app.lem: horum praecipua cura est in iure meretricibus dicendo, curandoque ut in omni civitate absque molestia esse possint.
app.rdg: whose main responsibility it is to preside over legal matters pertaining to prostitutes and to make sure that they can work untroubled all through the city.

app.lem: Accessit ad eos semel meretrix, questa iniuriam damnumque a tonsore illatum,
app.rdg: Once a prostitute came to this office and complained that she had suffered injury and damage from a barber.

app.lem: qui in balneum accersitus ab ea ut partes inferiores raderet, rasorio ita cunni partem incidit, ut pluribus diebus homines admittere nequivisset,
app.rdg: He had been summoned to the baths to shave her nether parts, but he had cut a part of the pussy with the razor so bad that she could not receive men for several days.

app.lem: ex quo damni infecti illum accusabat, amissi lucri restitutionem petens.
app.rdg: For this she accused him of anticipated damage and asked to be repaid the lost income.
